AUSTRALIA

Agriculture - Australia Bureau of Agricultural and Resources Economics reduced 2019/20 wheat output forecast to 21.2mln vs. Prev. 23.9mln tons. (Newswires)

Financials - Australian regulator APRA to revise some proposals to bank capital requirements related to credit cards, car loans and mortgages which will not require authorized deposit-taking institutions to hold any additional capital on top of target already announced. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Akebono Brake Industry (7238 JT) - Co. plans to hold discussions with creditors on July 22nd and is expected to make decision on turnaround plan in September. (Newswires)

Leopalace21 (8848 JT) - Co. plans to sell buildings to pay off costs related to repairs. (Newswires)

Nippon Steel and Sumitomo Metal (5401 JT) - Co. is to raise steel sheet prices effective next month. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Glass Lewis and Institutional Shareholder Service urge shareholder to vote against the reappointment of CEO Saikawa at the AGM on June 25th. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. unit Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) merger has been challenged by a group of US states. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Rotem (064350 KS) - Co. receives KRW 335.8bln order in Poland. (Newswires)

LG Group - Co. is reportedly mulling selling stakes in its IT division. (Yonhap)

Other News - BoK Governor Lee said will make appropriate policy response to economic changes and sees heightened external uncertainties. (Newswires)

Geopolitics

US President Trump said he received a "beautiful" letter from North Korean Leader Kim which was "very warm", while he added that North Korea has tremendous potential and thinks something positive will happen. (Newswires)

US National Security Advisor Bolton said a third US President Trump and North Korea Leader Kim summit is possible, with North Korea's Kim holding the key to this as the US is ready when they are. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said China wants to make a trade deal "very badly" and that the US will not do a deal with China unless it is a great deal, while he added that he is the one holding up the trade deal and expects to meet President Xi at the G20. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said either China tariffs will increase or a deal will be made and that he thinks a deal will eventually be made with China, but a definite deal cannot be made at the G20, while he also noted that the US has received more cooperation from China after tariffs were imposed. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow said once US President Trump and Chinese President Xi meet at the G20 "we can pick up where we left off" on the trade deal. Kudlow also commented that the US economy is in good shape and still thinks it is possible to get 3% growth, while he thinks the USMCA deal could add 0.5% growth. (Newswires)

White House Chief of Staff Mulvaney said Mexico deal will embolden US President Trump to be tougher on China. (Newswires)

US President Trump's former trade advisor Willems stated that there will not be a US-China deal at the G20 summit, although does expect a deal to occur in 3-6 months. (CNBC)

China Global Times Editor said there is no sign that China is relaxing countermeasures against the US and that China has no trust in mild signals the US sometimes send, while he suggested to be unoptimistic for a deal at G20. (Twitter)

 

UK/EU

BoE's Saunders (Hawk) said the UK could face more rate hikes in the event of a smooth Brexit and suggested that it may be appropriate to move rates more actively in either direction in a low rate environment than at a higher rate. Furthermore, BoE's Saunders said it is very useful for policy makers to give general guidance for outlook on policy, while he suggested they can cut close to zero but would not go negative and can expand QE asset purchases further if needed. (Newswires)

German Europe Minister Roth said they will not renegotiate the Withdrawal Agreement regardless of who the next UK PM is. (Newswires)

ECB's Rehn said the Bank could bolster forward guidance, lower rates, introduce mitigating measures from negative rates and resume QE if necessary. (Newswires)

ECB's Kazimir said they are confident they have the tools to achieve their target and the latest decisions prove their willingness to act, while he added that he doesn't see a recession or deflation ahead but are far from the inflation target. (Newswires)

Italy's Economy Minister Tria said the latest figures point to a deficit/GDP at 2.1/2.2% and that they will have a clearer indication in July. In other news, Italy are ready to back a French candidate to succeed ECB's Draghi according to sources. (Newswires)

  • UK Employment Change (Apr) 32k vs. Exp. 10k (Prev. 99k). (Newswires) 
  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Apr) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%) 
  • UK Average Weekly Earnings 3M (Apr) Y/Y 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 3.2%, Rev. 3.3%) 
  • UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Apr) 3.4% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.3%)

 

COMMODITIES

API Crude Inventories +4.9mln bbls vs. Exp. -0.5mln bbls (Prev. +3.55mln bbls). (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister Al-Mazrouei said OPEC+ is very close to an agreement for an extension, while he added that current inventories suggest curb should remain in place and suggested the deal should be extended at least until the end of the year. (Newswires)

Iranian officials are yet to agree on the new proposed dates to move the OPEC meeting from June to early July according to sources and the secretariat is looking at the option of holding OPEC meet in June and the non-OPEC in July. (Energy Intelligence)

US EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook report cut forecast for 2019 and 2020 world oil demand growth by 160k BPD and 110k BPD, respectively and now sees 1.22mln BPD and 1.42mln BPD Y/Y increases. (Newswires)

Alberta Premier said the government may have to consider extending oil curtailments into next year due to the delay of the line three pipeline. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he received a "beautiful" letter from North Korean Leader Kim which was "very warm", while he added that North Korea has tremendous potential and thinks something positive will happen. (Newswires)

US National Security Advisor Bolton said a third US President Trump and North Korea Leader Kim summit is possible, with North Korea's Kim holding the key to this as the US is ready when they are. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump tweeted that the biggest part of deal with Mexico has not yet been revealed and suggested that China is similar except they devalue currency and subsidize companies to lessen effect of the 25% tariff, while he suggested there is little effect to the consumer so far and that companies will relocate. Furthermore, President Trump also tweeted that EUR and other currencies are devalued against the USD which puts the US at a big disadvantage, while he also criticized the Fed for rates being too high and for quantitative tightening. (Twitter)

  • US PPI Final Demand (May) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires) 
  • US PPI Final Demand (May) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.2%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (APPL) and Broadcom (AVGO) both moved higher with the market, also supported by news the two had entered into an agreement, in which the latter will supply components for Apple’s smartphones, tablets and smart watches. Facebook (FB) was supported by an upgrade from Moffett Nathanson. US-listed Chinese stocks, including Baidu (BIDU), JD.com (JD), Weibo Corp (WB) and huya (HUYA) all rallied following signals overnight that Beijing will support Chinese growth. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher in spite of news of another autopilot malfunction, reported by a woman in San Francisco. CVS Health (CVS) was under pressure as news emerged that a US District Judge is mulling blocking the drug makers merger with Aetna. Beyond Meat (BYND) sunk after JPM downgraded the co., saying that above-the-Street expectations now appeared to be priced in. Lyft (LYF) jumped higher after receiving an upgrade from Susquehanna. Uber (UBER) and GrubHub (GRUB) shares were buoyed by news that Amazon’s (AMZN) competitor restaurant delivery service was exiting the market. T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S) both sunk after news emerged that ten US state AGs are planning to file a lawsuit as early as today to prevent the merger. Raytheon (RTN) and United Technologies (UTX) both sunk as investors had a second day to digest its proposed merger. FedEx Corp (FDX) was under pressure after being removed from Barclays’ top picks list. Insys Therapeutics (INSY) shares sunk further after Nasdaq discarded the stock. Dollar Tree (DLTR) jumped higher on a JPM upgrade. LyondellBasell (LYB) moved higher after Jefferies raised its profit target for the firm on their proposed share buy-back programme. A number of banks, including Citigroup (C), Morgan Stanley (MS) and State Street (STT) made cautious comments regarding trading revenue for Q2; all saw negative ticks, especially State Street, whose shares plummeted. S&P 500 0% at 2886, NASDAQ-100 0.2% at 7514, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26049.

A roller-coaster session saw the T-Note future slip to 126-07 in European trade, after China stimulus measures stoked risk sentiment; however, the risk tone became more neutral (some desks cited "fading trade optimism", although a more distinct and convincing reason for the Treasury bid and the equity downside was more ellusive), the complex slowly grinded its way up towards flat levels by settlement. The 3-year auction was solid, stopping through the screens by 0.6bps on cover above recent averages. Crucially, the indirect bid (a proxy for foreign participation) actually rose to 56.6% from 37.9% (average 44.7% over the previous six), which was a relief to the analysts that had expected a weak showing after recent data showed foreign central banks reduced their UST holdings in the latest week by the most since April 2018. Some have speculated that the recent foreign cbank selling might be linked to China selling Treasuries to stem the slide in the yuan since May. At settlement, major curve spreads were narrower, with 2s30s coming in by around 3bps, 2s5s flatter by around 2bps. Tomorrow, the US sells 10-year notes; last month’s auction was weak, seeing a 1.2bps tail. Investment funds cut their takedown (to 45% from 62% at the previous 10-year auction. Recent averages suggest the auction will stop on the screw, with a 75% buy-side takedown (13% direct, 62% indirect). TD Securities notes that the 10-year trades special in repo, which could signal strong demand at the auction. T-note futures (M9) settled unchanged at 126-14.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 11th June 2019: Equities, T-note, Crude, Dollar all flat ahead of Wednesday’s CPI
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites flat, Treasuries flat, Dollar flat, Crude flat.
  • REAR VIEW: US President Trump jawboning on Mexico/China fails to move the dial; Strong UK employment data; BoE’s Saunders comments more neutral, ECB’s Kazimir comments confirm weekend ECB sources that FX will play a role in policy making; US PPI mixed, NFIB decent.
  • COMING UP: JN Corporate Goods Price; AU Consumer Sentiment; CH CPI; US CPI, EIA Weekly Crude Stocks; RBA’s Kent; Riksbank’s Floden; ECB’s Draghi, de Guindos, Coeure; GE EUR 3bln 10yr Auction, US USD 24bln 10yr Auction

 

* CHINA: China continues to wield the threat of rare earth mineral export restrictions to the US; Chinese authorities have begun a survey into rare earth resources in multiple provinces and regions on Monday, reported the Chinese press. US President Trump was vocal in his criticisms/opinions for a second day: accusing China of the devaluing their currency and subsidizing companies to lessen effect of 25% tariff.  He also said China wants to make a trade deal "very badly" and will not do a deal with China unless it is a great deal whilst going as far saying that he is the one holding up the trade deal (possibly implying that he is holding out for a “great deal”). On a slightly softer note Trump did also say that he expects to meet Chinese President Xi at the G20. Comments from US Commerce Secretary Ross added to the feeling that the outcome of the G20 meeting, at which the market will be hoping for some form of “trade truce” between the US and China (similar to what happened last November), will likely be a binary one, where he said that either China tariffs will be increased or a deal will be made (Trump has previously hinted that he will wait and see how the G20 goes before deciding on further China tariffs). Ross did also add that he expects a deal to be reached eventually and noted that he does not expect a deal to be reached at the G20. Later, White House Chief of Staff Mulvaney suggested that the recent Mexico deal will embolden US President Trump to be tougher on China. US NEC Director Kudlow was upbeat on the prospect of a deal: saying once Trump and Xi meet at the G20 "we can pick up where we left off" with regards to the trade deal. China’s Global Times Editor, however, was less optimistic on the prospect on a deal being reached on at the G20, whilst also saying that there is no sign that China is relaxing countermeasures against the US and that China does not trust the mild signals the US sometimes sends.

* MEXICO: President Trump on Tuesday teased the market, saying that “The biggest part of deal with Mexico has not yet been revealed!” What exactly this might be remains unclear, especially given the fact that US President Trump’s weekend claims that Mexico were to commence large purchases of US agricultural goods were duly denied by Mexico’s Foreign Minister Ebrard yesterday. Elsewhere, Mexican Foreign Minister said that Mexico will be paying for the migration measures with its own funds. Later, Newswires reported that the US/Mexico deal document held by US President Trump outside the White House outlined a regional asylum plan with Mexico and also says Mexico will look into domestic laws and regulations with a view to make possible changes.

* ECB: ECB's Rehn suggested that the bank could bolster forward guidance, lower rates, and introduce measures to mitigate the impact of negative rates and resume QE, if necessary. He also reasserted that central bank is determined to act in the event of further weakening of economic activity. Further, regarding Eurozone inflation expectations, which recently receded to record lows, Rehn conceded that the ECB's price stability goal will be hampered in the event of low inflation expectations. ECB’s Kazimir noted his confidence that the ECB has the tools necessary to achieve its target and that the bank’s latest decisions prove its willingness to act. Kazimir also noted that he didn’t see a recession or deflation in the near future but the Eurozone remains far from their inflation target and that the ECB is not at a point where more policy tools need to be used. In line with the sources report from the weekend, Kazmir said FX is a factor the ECB considers in policy deliberations. (NOTE: on the weekend, a Reuters sources piece suggested that the ECB would be open to rate cuts if the EZ economy slows, while also suggesting that Euro strength would form part of the reason to cut rates.)

* US PPI: Producer prices rose by 0.1% M/M in May, in line with the consensus view; core rose 0.2% M/M a touch ahead of expectations. The Y/Y headline fell by more than expected, to 1.8% vs 2.0% exp and previous 2.2%, largely due to energy, food, and other non-core categories weighing on the headline. The data fuelled further analysts to raise the possibility of Fed rate cuts; Oxford Economics said “with risks rising again on the trade front and core consumer prices persistently below the Fed’s target, we now look for the Fed to implement a 25bp rate cut in December.”

* US NFIB: Optimism among smaller US firms rose by 1.5 points to 105.0 in May, the highest since October. Capex plans rose, inflationary pressures fell. Labour market components, much of which were released last week, were strong. “Despite trade uncertainty, owners are confident about future prospects,” Wells Fargo said, “notably, 30% of firms plan to increase capital spending out lays, a historically high level and up three points during the month.” The inflation moderation suggests slowing demand might be curbing pricing power, WFC said.

* GEOPOLITICAL: US President Trump said he believes something positive will happen between the US and North Korea, after saying he received a “beautiful” letter from Kim Jong Un. National Security Advisor John Bolton also said earlier that a third US-North Korea summit is a possibility, and the US is ready when NK is.

* UK JOBS DATA: A strong jobs report where the rate of joblessness remained unchanged, and the decline of average weekly wages (inc bonus) was more benign than the consensus had estimated, while total hours increased. Vacancies, meanwhile, are lower versus earlier in the year, but remain high historically, analysts said. The big takeaway was wages ex bonuses rose to 3.8% Y/Y, the highest since May 2008, on the back of a large rise in public sector wages, though the tightness of the labour market is also a factor cited by analysts. “With the labour market unlikely to weaken suddenly soon and government policies set to remain supportive of faster wage growth, the MPC can’t afford to ignore the constant inflation pressure now emitted by the labour market,” Pantheon Macroeconomics said.

* BOE: After yesterday’s hawkish comments from BoE's Saunders, where he (and BoE’s Haldane) suggested that the Bank might have to raise rates due to inflationary pressures, and despite the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, Saunders provided a more balanced view, and in more general terms described the banks reaction function to the downside; he said the BOE could lower rates to zero, but not below, and it could restart QE. He also added that, at lower rates, it may be appropriate to move rates more actively in either direction than at higher rates. Today’s strong employment report gave further credence to the argument for rate hikes, analysts said. BoE’s Broadbent and Vlieghe both also spoke today, both towing the neutral line in saying that they agree with the BoE’s May forecasts.

* BREXIT: Following on from comments from Conservative front-runner Boris Johnson on Monday, in which he threatened to withhold from the EU the previously agreed GBP 39bln divorce bill and promised to reopen negotiations on the withdrawal agreement, German Europe Minister Roth took a tough line: saying that the EU will not renegotiate the Withdrawal Agreement, regardless of who the next PM is.

* CBRT PREVIEW: CBRT Rate Decision (June 2019) will be published on Wednesday 12th June 2019, at 12:00BST/0700EDT: The CBRT rate decision will be published on Wednesday 12th June 2019, at 12:00BST/0700EDT. The central bank is expected to hold rates at 24.00%, despite improving inflation dynamics, more favourable FX movements; these will likely see the CBRT cautious on signalling any rate cuts, while any tightening bias is not foreseen following the removal in April. To download the report, please click here.

* FX WRAP: USD trades flat, off highs with mixed PPI data doing little to rock the boat, with desks attributing marginal downside to cooling global trade optimism. EUR edged higher, largely a function of the buck, but also supported by decent Sentex data. GBP was one of the outperformers on the day; strong employment data added credence to hawkish comments from BoE members, who have been talking up the need for gradual rate hikes to counter inflationary pressures despite continued Brexit related uncertainty. Cable has consolidated above 1.2700 in response. JPY is trading flat: despite dovish commentary from Kuroda. NOK saw choppy price action, popping lower after disappointing consumer price index data before reversing the move after a robust Norges Bank regional survey that keeps the Scandi CB on course for further policy normalisation next Thursday. AUD continues to consolidate around 69.50 ahead of this week’s jobs report, which will set the tone for the upcoming RBA meeting; NAB data overnight employment subcomponent was encouraging. TRY was an underperformer in the EM complex, as US/Turkey geopolitical tensions weighed. ZAR is outperforming EMFX, continuing the rebound despite concerns over the Eskom bailout. BRL continues to gain in the slipstream of Mexico averting tariffs, while hopes of pension reform are also underpinning. MXN continues to build on gains post avoiding US tariffs, but underperforms EMFX, with some desks suggesting this is perhaps due to challenges that remain with regards to enforcing the immigration agreement. For more in-depth analysis, please click here.

* S&P 500 0% at 2886, NASDAQ-100 0.2% at 7514, Dow Jones -0.1% at 26049; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.3%, Consumer Staples 0.4%, Energy 0.1%, Financials 0%, Health Care -0.3%, Industrials -0.9%, Information Technology 0%, Materials -0.1%, Telecommunication Services 0.3%, Utilities -0.7%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (APPL) and Broadcom (AVGO) both moved higher with the market, also supported by news the two had entered into an agreement, in which the latter will supply components for Apple’s smartphones, tablets and smart watches. Facebook (FB) was supported by an upgrade from Moffett Nathanson. US-listed Chinese stocks, including Baidu (BIDU), JD.com (JD), Weibo Corp (WB) and huya (HUYA) all rallied following signals overnight that Beijing will support Chinese growth. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher in spite of news of another autopilot malfunction, reported by a woman in San Francisco. CVS Health (CVS) was under pressure as news emerged that a US District Judge is mulling blocking the drug makers merger with Aetna. Beyond Meat (BYND) sunk after JPM downgraded the co., saying that above-the-Street expectations now appeared to be priced in. Lyft (LYF) jumped higher after receiving an upgrade from Susquehanna. Uber (UBER) and GrubHub (GRUB) shares were buoyed by news that Amazon’s (AMZN) competitor restaurant delivery service was exiting the market. T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Sprint (S) both sunk after news emerged that ten US state AGs are planning to file a lawsuit as early as today to prevent the merger. Raytheon (RTN) and United Technologies (UTX) both sunk as investors had a second day to digest its proposed merger. FedEx Corp (FDX) was under pressure after being removed from Barclays’ top picks list. Insys Therapeutics (INSY) shares sunk further after Nasdaq discarded the stock. Dollar Tree (DLTR) jumped higher on a JPM upgrade. LyondellBasell (LYB) moved higher after Jefferies raised its profit target for the firm on their proposed share buy-back programme. A number of banks, including Citigroup (C), Morgan Stanley (MS) and State Street (STT) made cautious comments regarding trading revenue for Q2; all saw negative ticks, especially State Street, whose shares plummeted.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.01 HIGHER AT USD 53.27/BBL; BRENT (Q9) FUTURES SETTLE UNCHANGED AT 62.29/BBL: Oil prices edged higher on Tuesday in what was a choppy session. As usual, there are several factors to be considered, PVM’s analysts note, “those of a bullish disposition take heart from mounting expectations that OPEC-led cuts will be extended throughout 2019.” Regarding the meeting, Iranian officials are yet to agree on the new proposed dates to move the OPEC meeting from June to early July; the Secretariat is looking at the option of holding OPEC meet in June and the non-OPEC in July. Essentially no consensus yet. WTI is likely catching some momentum ahead of the weekly US energy inventories (APIs after the bell on Tuesday) where current expectations see crude stocks drawing -0.5mln bbls, and the products building (+1.1mln bbls for distillates, +0.7mln bbls for gasoline). A similar print as last week would pose a real risk to the market, where the EIA report was bearish on all fronts and production stood at record highs. The large build in crude was accompanied with similar readings in the products, raising concerns about demand in what is meant to be the start of the historically strong summer runs out of refineries.

* EIA STEO: The EIA cut its forecast for 2019 and 2020 oil demand growth by 160k BPD and 110k BPD, respectively, and now sees 1.22mln BPD and 1.42mln BPD YY increases. It sees US crude output rising 1.36mln BPD in 2019 to 12.32mln BPD (compared with the 1.49mln BPD increase in the prior month); sees US crude output rising 94k to 13.26mln BPD in 2020 (compared with the 93K BPD increase previously).

* T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE UNCHANGED AT 126-14: A roller-coaster session saw the T-Note future slip to 126-07 in European trade, after China stimulus measures stoked risk sentiment; however, the risk tone became more neutral (some desks cited "fading trade optimism", although a more distinct and convincing reason for the Treasury bid and the equity downside was more ellusive), the complex slowly grinded its way up towards flat levels by settlement. subject: FX WRAP: USD little moved as EMs advance
content:
* FX WRAP: USD trades flat, off highs with mixed PPI data doing little to rock the boat, with desks attributing marginal downside to cooling global trade optimism. EUR edged higher, largely a function of the buck, but also supported by decent Sentex data. GBP was one of the outperformers on the day; strong employment data added credence to hawkish comments from BoE members, who have been talking up the need for gradual rate hikes to counter inflationary pressures despite continued Brexit related uncertainty. Cable has consolidated above 1.2700 in response. JPY is trading flat: despite dovish commentary from Kuroda. NOK saw choppy price action, popping lower after disappointing consumer price index data before reversing the move after a robust Norges Bank regional survey that keeps the Scandi CB on course for further policy normalisation next Thursday. AUD continues to consolidate around 69.50 ahead of this week’s jobs report, which will set the tone for the upcoming RBA meeting; NAB data overnight employment subcomponent was encouraging. TRY was an underperformer in the EM complex, as US/Turkey geopolitical tensions weighed. ZAR is outperforming EM FX, continuing the rebound despite concerns over the Eskom bailout. BRL continues to gain in the slipstream of Mexico averting tariffs, while hopes of pension reform are also underpinning. MXN continues to build on gains post avoiding US tariffs, but underperforms EM FX, with some desks suggesting this is perhaps due to challenges that remain with regards to enforcing the immigration agreement.

* EUR: Deutsche Bank notes the impressive rally in the EUR over the last 10 trading days, which has seen the EUR move from a 1.11-1.12 range to a 1.13 handle; but DB questions that with Trump casting his eye on Europe, and political tensions in Italy, and sees this as a preferred area to fade the move back to the 200dma, towards the March high. However, ahead of the FOMC meeting next week, the bank suggests consolidation may be a theme.

* AUD: Position adjustment is being cited ahead of Thursday’s jobs report, which will be a key input into whether the RBA decides to cut rates at its next meeting. The employment component in the NAB survey improved overnight, as did confidence, though conditions remains weak. Desks are noting that the RBA pricing and AUD seem in sync for now, making it difficult to take high conviction views of the AUD. The USD part of the equation may be more influential with CPI and retail sales this week.

* JPY: BOJ governor Kuroda has warned that if the FOMC were to cut rates, the BOJ has room to lower its -10bps rate even lower, while it can also reduce the target for JGB yields and also boost its monetary base. USDJPY seems well supported around 108.00, and even the knee-jerk reaction after the “weak” payrolls report could not keep the pair sub 108. Much will depend on how US fixed income trades, and specifically, the pricing for July’s Fed meeting; some desks have suggested that if that rate cut pricing does not ease, the USD rally might run out of steam, bringing sub-108 back into focus.

* CNY: PBOC overnight said it would sell yuan-denominated bills in Hong Kong in late June, a measure analysts have said helps the central bank to control offshore liquidity. It would be the fourth occasion in recent months when it has issued bills in HK. The timeframe is particularly interesting given the G20 meeting on 28-29 June, where US and Chinese policymakers are expected to discuss trade.

* ZAR: The rand has rebounded from YTD lows seen last week, on concerns that the government will have to raise issuance in order to rescue Eskom. Some desks warn that local bond markets could see further outflows, particularly after Moody’s warned that the shock Q1 GDP contraction was credit negative. SocGen notes foreign investors have cut ZAR bond holdings from 42.8% in March last year, to 39.2% currently.

* NOK: Inflation downside surprise was driven by air fares, with CPI-ATE 2.3% Y/Y, below the Norges Bank’s 2.5% Y/Y forecast. The Norges Bank is the only G10 central bank where markets are pricing in a rate hike in the near-term, and SEB believes that the downside surprise does not derail the hawkish case: “core inflation has been above the target for seven consecutive months and despite today’s downside surprise, it remains an argument for tighter monetary policy.” SEB still sees the Norges Bank lifting its key rate to 1.25% at the 20th June meeting. It does warn, however, that as a result of the inflation print, the NB may want to revise its rate hike trajectory modestly narrower. “The impact on the rate path may, however, will be minor; prices on air tickets are notoriously volatile, the import-weighted krone is weaker than assumed and the labour market remains strong. Norges Bank’s long-term trajectory puts CPI-ATE inflation at the 2% target until end 2022.”

subject: The Migration deal document held by US President Trump outside the White House outlined a regional asylum plan with Mexico, says Mexico will look into domestic laws and regulations with a view to make possible changes
WTI (N9) futures settle USD 0.01 higher at USD 53.27/BBL; Brent (Q9) futures settle unchanged at 62.29/BBL
analysis_details: Oil prices edged higher on Tuesday in what was a choppy session. As usual, there are several factors to be considered, PVM’s analysts note, “those of a bullish disposition take heart from mounting expectations that OPEC-led cuts will be extended throughout 2019.” Regarding the meeting, Iranian officials are yet to agree on the new proposed dates to move the OPEC meeting from June to early July; the Secretariat is looking at the option of holding OPEC meet in June and the non-OPEC in July. Essentially no consensus yet. WTI is likely catching some momentum ahead of the weekly US energy inventories (APIs after the bell on Tuesday) where current expectations see crude stocks drawing -0.5mln bbls, and the products building (+1.1mln bbls for distillates, +0.7mln bbls for gasoline). A similar print as last week would pose a real risk to the market, where the EIA report was bearish on all fronts and production stood at record highs. The large build in crude was accompanied with similar readings in the products, raising concerns about demand in what is meant to be the start of the historically strong summer runs out of refineries.

subject: PREVIEW: US to auction USD 38bln in 3-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
* THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: The US will auction USD 78bln in 3-year (USD 38bln, Tue), 10-year (USD 24bln, Weds), 30-year (USD 16bln, Thu). With USD 24bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, the supply will raise a net USD 54bln of new cash. TD Securities points out that the Fed’s portfolio run-ff has slowed to USD 15bln in Treasuries, versus USD 30bln previous, however, with no SOMA maturities in the mid-month, the Fed is set to conduct its add-ons later in the month.

* 3-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Recent auctions have been mixed, with some desks suggesting that lower rates are a factor. With that said, recent speculation that the Fed could fire some “insurance” rate cuts might be supportive. Recent averages suggest we could see a tail at the 3-year auction of 0.3bps, with 61% buy-side takedown (16% to directs, and 45% to indirects).

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar somewhat mixed vs majors and EMs, as DXY remains capped below 97.000
content:
USD

The Dollar perked up a bit in wake of largely as expected US PPI data, headline y/y aside, but the index only managed to eke out a marginal new EU session high before fading ahead of the 97.000 marker again. Usd/G10 pairings are back within broad ranges, while EM currencies are mostly firmer vs the Greenback, bar the Lira, as the DXY holds between 96.893-673. Note, comments from US President Trump bemoaning Euro and other currency devaluation vs the Usd, alongside another tirade against the Fed for hiking too much and running down the balance sheet were largely shrugged off.

GBP/NOK/EUR/CAD

The major outperformers or most resilient to Buck bounces, as the Pound drew encouragement from firmer than forecast UK wages and more hawkish BoE commentary following yesterday’s underperformance on bleak GDP, ip, manufacturing and construction output. Cable consolidated above 1.2700 in response and Eur/Gbp pared back from new multi-week peaks around 0.8930 to just under 0.8900. Similarly, Eur/Nok reversed from 9.8300+ levels and test of decent upside resistance to and through pre-Norwegian inflation data levels as softer than expected CPI prints were more than offset by a robust Norges Bank regional survey that keeps the Scandi CB on course for further policy normalisation next Thursday. Eur/Nok currently testing 9.7600 in contrast to Eur/Sek above 10.6800 in the run up to Swedish inflation at the end of the week. Turning to the single currency itself, and apart from the aforementioned Trump broadside, bearish impulses included a negative Sentix index and dovish ECB Rehn rhetoric, but Eur/Usd held just above 1.1300 where decent option expiry interest rolled off at the NY cut. Elsewhere, the Loonie meandered between 1.3250-77 and will maintain bullish momentum to augment post-strong Canadian labour market gains if it closes above the 200 DMA (1.3273).

AUD/JPY/CHF/NZD

All on the backfoot vs the Greenback, to varying degrees, as the Aussie hovers around 0.6950 and derives some indirect support from cross winds undermining the Kiwi that is technically if not fundamentally weaker in the face of a potential NZ live cattle export ban. Indeed, Nzd/Usd slipped further from 0.6600 to 0.6570 as Aud/Nzd extended its rebound from near 1.0500 lows to 1.0580 and Nzd/Jpy saw further declines through stops through 71.50. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy and Usd/Chf both traded nearer the top of 108.80-36 and 0.99936-0.9893 respective parameters on the US-Mexican trade deal risk supportive vibe, and with the Yen also taking on board latest pledges by the Japanese Government to support the economy, while the Franc anticipates ongoing dovish guidance from the SNB on Thursday.

EM

The Rand has continued its recovery from recent lows under 15.0000 vs the Usd with the aid of solid SA manufacturing data, but the Lira has retreated further amidst more US vs Turkey-Russia missile angst and as the focus turns to Wednesday’s CBRT policy meeting with the tone key for further direction. Usd/Zar sub-14.6850 and Usd/Try hovering around 5.8300.

However, Gilts are still lagging on better than forecast UK wage data and hawkish fare from the BoE, with Sterling also benefiting as the Dollar attempted to climb on the back of US PPI that was broadly in line with consensus bar the y/y headline and has allayed some risks of a big downside CPI miss. subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 11th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has entered into a statement of work with certain subsidiaries of Broadcom (AVGO) (Information Technology/Semiconductors), according to a Broadcom regulatory filing on Sunday, agreeing to provide components for smartphones, tablets and watches. Separately, the head of Foxconn’s (FXCOF) semiconductor business group Liu, said that while Apple and Huawei have made some changes to their orders in response to US/China trade tensions, he sees “limited” impact on the company. However, newswires reported that if the US/China trade war continues to escalate, Foxconn will have enough capacity to make all iPhones headed for the U.S. outside of China, citing a senior executive at Hon Hai Precision.

Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) and Airbus (EADSY, AIR FP) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) are reportedly battling over USD 10bln worth of wide-body aircraft orders ahead of the Paris Airshow next week. The two aircraft makers will attempt to court Philippine airline Cebu Air, with Airbus looking for a buyer of its A330neo aircraft. However, Cebu Air is reportedly mulling breaking exclusive ties with Airbus and choosing Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner, as it looks to secure 16 wide-body aircraft to be delivered in 2020 and 2021.

Intel Corp (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) is to acquire Barefoot Networks, although terms have not been given.

Merck & Co (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced that the FDA have approved KEYTRUDA, an anti-PD-1 therapy, after the drug demonstrated a significant improvement in overall survival compared to the standard treatment.

Visa Inc (V) (Information Technology/IT Services) announced the launch of a new network, which aims to help financial institutions process cross-border payments on behalf of corporate clients faster and at a lower operational cost. Visa’s B2B Connect network will cover 30 global trade corridors, while they expect to expand to 90 markets by year-end.

NASDAQ 100

Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) will close its restaurant delivery service, called Amazon Restaurants, in the US, as well as Daily Dish, a workplace lunch delivery service that it launched in 2016. Amazon Restaurants competitors Uber Eats (UBER) and GrubHub (GRUB) look set to benefit. Elsewhere, the head of Amazon's cloud computing division on Monday said the company would work with any government agency that followed the law, in contrast with Microsoft (MSFT) who has suggested it may reject some controversial government sales.

Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) said that users are not allowed to post ads or pay to promote posts that mention CBD-infused products, the Verge reported. Elsewhere, the social media platform will launch new Portal video-chat devices in Fall 2019.

Netflix (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) and Ubisoft (UBSFY) (Communication Services/Entertainment) are teaming up to create a movie based on the later’s “Tom Clancy’s The Division” video game, the two co.s announced at E3.

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) - A woman has claimed her new Tesla auto-accelerated into her garage and that Tesla have not been responsive following the claims.

S&P 500

Citigroup (C) (Financials/Diversified Banks) is partnering with a Singapore-based ride-hailing service called Grab to launch co-branded credit cards. This move comes as Citi looks to increase its Asian customer base by 13% through collaborations with digital firms.

CVS Health (CVS) (Health Care/Health Care Services) – A US District Judge Leon appears to be close to blocking CVS Health’s USD 69bln acquisition of Aetna, reports the NYT, on concerns that it could raise prices and hurt choices for consumers.

Lockheed Martin (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) – Turkish pilots have ended their F-35 fighter jet training at a US base sooner than expected, with the US saying that Turkey’s plans to go ahead with the purchase of Russia’s S-400 missile system is a threat to the F-35 jet. The F-35 is built by Lockheed Martin. Separately, New Zealand announced it had chosen Lockheed Martin's C-130J Super Hercules as its preferred replacement for its five ageing C-130 Hercules military transport aircraft.

Phillips 66 (PSX) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) and Plains All American Pipeline (PAA) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) announced that they have formed a 50/50 joint venture, which is called Red Oak Pipeline LLC, and will proceed with the construction of both the Red Oak Pipeline system (costing USD 2.5bln) and the Liberty Pipeline (costing USD 1.6bln).

Whirlpool (WHR) (Consumer Discretionary/Household Appliances) - Italian Deputy Prime Minister Di Maio said in a radio interview that the government will cut incentives for Whirlpool, after the company opted to close its Naples manufacturing facility.

OTHER

Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) announced that its voice-controlled assistant will feature in Audi, Renault and Honda vehicles, as the tech giant expands in artificial intelligence.

Apollo Global Management (APO) (Financials/Capital Markets) will acquire all outstanding shares of Shutterfly (SFLY) for USD 51 in cash, valuing the firm at roughly USD 2.7bln. As part of the acquisition, Apollo will combine Snapfish and Shutterfly.

Barnes & Noble (BKS) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) announced last Friday that it had agreed to be acquired by Elliott Management for USD 6.50 per share. However, book distributor Readerlink LLC is reportedly working on making a higher bid.

Beyond Meat (BYND) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) – According to research by S3 Partners, short sellers have lost over USD 400mln betting against the plant-based burger maker since it went public. Separately, JP Morgan downgraded the co. to neutral from overweight, saying that it above-the-Street estimates now appear to be priced in.

Renault (RNSDF, RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles), Fiat Chrysler (FCAU, FCA IM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) – Speculation that merger talks between the two automakers grew in the early hours of this morning, after comments from the French transport Minister, who, when asked if talks were over, said, "I think it is not closed."

Toyota Motor Corp’s (TM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) self-driving car joint venture with SoftBank plans to begin operations in Southeast Asia next year, marking its first overseas foray, said the chief executive.

Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Rail & Road) competitor Bolt, previously called Taxify, plans to launch in London this week after it stopped operations in 2017 following a Transport for London investigation, reported TechCrunch.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are firmer this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.9%], taking the lead from a positive Asia-Pac session.
  • In FX, Sterling is outperforming G10 counterparts on the combination of both strong UK labour data and hawkish BoE speak
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US PPI. Supply from the US

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were higher across the board after a similar lead from US where sentiment was underpinned by the US-Mexico tariff relief which lifted the S&P 500 and DJIA to a 5-day and 6-day win streak respectively, although gains in the region were initially capped amid a lack of fresh catalysts. ASX 200 (+1.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) traded positively with early outperformance in Australia as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend and with Vocus Group the largest gainer following a takeover offer from AGL Energy, while the Japanese benchmark was just about kept afloat by a weaker currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.6%) conformed to the upbeat tone despite another net liquidity drain by the PBoC and mixed comments by US President Trump who stated that a trade deal with China will work out because of tariffs but warned the next USD 300bln of tariffs will come into effect if Chinese President Xi does not come to the G20. Nonetheless, mainland China outperformed after China issued notice encouraging investment in local government special bonds issuance for project financing and amid reports that the PBoC may continue to support banks through various tools. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as yields tracked the rebound in their US counterparts and with demand for Japanese bonds also sapped by gains in stocks and after weaker demand in the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds.

PBoC injected CNY 10bln via 7-day reverse repos for a daily net drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8930 (Prev. 6.8925)

PBoC may continue to support banks through various tools including RRR, MLF and SLF, while there were separate reports that Chinese companies have been scaling back or halting investment in the US market. (China Securities Journal/SCMP)

Chinese authorities have reportedly begun a survey into rare earth resources in multiple provinces and regions on Monday., China Securities Journal. (Newswires)

US

President Trump stated that the US has an agreement on something with Mexico that they will announce very soon and that he does not think Mexico will be denying for very long the undisclosed portion of the agreement. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK/EU

BoE's Saunders (Hawk) said the BoE will likely need to return to neutral policy stance sooner than the market expects and that the MPC doesn't necessarily need to keep rates unchanged until Brexit uncertainties are resolved. Saunders added that BoE's neutral rate is around 2% and suggested that they should not just look at Brexit uncertainty and instead should look at growth as well as assess whether or not it is above or below potential when setting interest rate. Subsequently, Saunders stated that the UK could face more rate hikes in the event of a smooth Brexit, and the rate could be cut close to zero but would not go negative and QE asset purchases can be expanded if necessary.

UK right-wing Tory caucus held a non-binding vote to gauge support in which Boris Johnson received the most votes as the results from the 92 Group vote showed Johnson received 34 votes, Raab at 18 votes, Gove at 6 votes, McVey at 6 votes, Harper at 5 votes, Javid at 5 votes, Hunt at 2 votes and Leadsom at 2 votes. (Newswires)

EU Source indicates that the idea of Boris Johnson in the European Council is ‘likely abhorrent’ to some EU leaders, with the source also critical of Dominic Raab. (Guardian)

UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Apr) 3.4% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.3%)

- UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY (Apr) 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 3.2%, Rev. 3.3%)

- UK Employment Change (Apr) 32k vs. Exp. 10k (Prev. 99k)

- UK Claimant Count Unem Chng (May) 23.2k vs. Exp. 22.9k (Prev. 24.7k, Rev. 19.1k)

- UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Apr) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%)

ECB's Rehn (Neutral) says the Bank could bolster forward guidance, lower rates, introduce mitigating measures from negative rates and resume QE if necessary, are determined to act in the event of further economic activity weakening and the price stability goal will be hampered in the event of low inflation expectations. (Newswires)

Italy PM Conte will meet with Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio in approaching days to complete action plan for entire legislature and want to avert EU disciplinary action against Italy, while they will meet with Finance Minister Tria on budget package. Subsequently, Deputy PM Salvini says they will advert EU deficit procedure with growth and tax cuts. Both Deputy PM Di Maio and PM Conte stated that the coalition meeting went well. While PM Conte has stated they believe the 2019 deficit/GDP ratio can be reduced to 2.2%. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea state media called on the US to “withdraw its hostile policy” towards Pyongyang or agreements made at the Singapore summit 1 year ago may become “a blank sheet of paper". (Newswires)

Chinese press reports stated the US Air Force is preparing to run through aggressor drills to simulate combat with China's J-20 fighter jets, while it was also reported that China and Russia are expected to form an alliance to fend off the US. (SCMP)

Reported that the IAEA stated Iran has accelerated enrichment of uranium. (Newswires) Follows on from yesteday’s UN Nuclear Watchdog Chief states that iran’s enriched uranium production rate is increasing. (Newswires)

Turkey’s Foreign Ministry has ‘slammed the unacceptable’ US resolution which condemns Turkey’s decision to acquire the S-400 missile system; Turkey’s Ministry stated the resolution does not align with the relationship between Turkey and the US. (Anadolu)

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +0.9%] following on from a similar lead in Asia wherein Mainland China closed with gains in excess of 2.5%. Germany’s DAX (+1.3%) is outperforming its peers as the index plays catch-up following yesterday’s holiday. Sectors are broadly in the green with the exception of defensive sectors amid the current “risk on” mood, whilst material names are outperforming as Dalian iron ore futures spiked 6% higher on supply concerns and copper prices rose almost 1% on the firmer risk sentiment. In terms of in individual movers, Thyssenkrupp (+5.5%) sits near the top of the Stoxx 600 as the steel name benefits from the aforementioned iron ore spike. Elsewhere, German autos are supported (BMW +1.6%, Daimler +1.8%, Volkswagen +1.8%) as the stocks react to the weekend US-Mexico developments for the first time. Finally, Hugo Boss (+4.3%) shares were bolstered amid an upgrade at Morgan Stanley.

FX

GBP - More hawkish leaning BoE rhetoric, as Saunders follows Haldane on the rate hike path has been validated to a degree by the latest UK labour report revealing firmer than forecast wages, and in particular an unexpected pick-up in ex-bonus earnings, in stark contrast to Monday’s dismal GDP and industrial output figures. Hence, the Pound has rebounded across the board with Cable back above 1.2700 and testing yesterday’s pre-data peaks ahead of resistance seen around 1.2740, while Eur/Gbp has reversed from fresh multi-week highs circa 0.8932 through 0.8900.

NZD/JPY/CHF/AUD - In contrast to Sterling’s revival, the Kiwi has extended losses to 0.6588 vs its US counterpart and 1.0550+ against the Aussie, which is also weak compared to the Buck but holding up better around 0.6950 ahead of jobs data on Thursday. Nzd/Usd saw accelerated selling on a break of 0.6600 and market participants also noted stops in Nzd/Jpy when 71.81 failed to hold, with a variety of model and spec offers pushing the cross down to 71.54. Similarly, the Yen and Franc have weakened a bit further vs the Dollar as the DXY sits tight between 96.832-673, with Usd/Jpy hovering above 108.50 within a 108.36-73 range and Usd/Chf holding closer to the upper end of a 0.9923-0.9893 band. Note, however, Usd/Jpy may well be drawn towards decent option expiry interest at 108.50 in 1.1 bn.

CAD/EUR - The Loonie continues to outperform, as technical impulses turn increasingly bullish and Usd/Cad trade below the 200 DMA (1.3273) towards 1.3250 and post-NA jobs data lows of 1.3225, while the single currency remains above 1.1300 where more expiries lie (1.1 bn) even though Eurozone Sentix sentiment soured significantly and ECB’s Rehn reiterated that all monetary stimulus options will be available if growth weakens further. On the flip-side, Eur/Usd is still butting up against resistance ahead of 1.1350 and the 200 DMA (1.1365), including option barriers and more expiries, like 2.3 bn from 1.1340 to 1.1350 and 2.8 bn at 1.1360.

NOK - The Norwegian Crown slipped in wake of considerably sub-consensus CPI metrics that called into question firm Norges Bank guidance for a rate hike at this month’s policy meeting, but Eur/Nok reversed from a probe over resistance around 9.8300 to revisit pre-inflation data levels sub-9.7800 on the back of an upbeat regional survey that restored June tightening expectations. Conversely, Eur/Sek has seen more upside towards 10.6900 ahead of Sweden’s inflation update on Friday and potential pointers from Prospera’s expectations survey tomorrow.

FIXED INCOME

Post-UK data losses for UK bonds and STIRs are piling up through BoE testimony and more signs that MPC members may not be completely beholden to the fate of Brexit in terms of tweaking policy, while the latest snapshot of the labour market is also conducive to normalisation in contrast to Monday’s bleak ‘activity’ data. The 10 year debt future just hit a fresh Liffe low at 129.90 (-44 ticks on the day) and 3 month contracts are as much as 6.5 ticks adrift, while USTs are succumbing to more pronounced bear-steepening into supply and PPI, with Bunds being dragged down in sympathy it seems.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.8%) and Brent (-0.3%) futures are choppy as the benchmarks are benefitting from the improved risk tone,with the former around USD 62.50/bbl and the latter hitting a session peak just under USD 54.00/bbl. News flow has been light for the complex as participants eye tonight’s EIA Short term Energy Outlook report and API inventories release with the street looking for a headline draw of 1.25mln barrels. Elsewhere, Energy Intel’s Senior Correspondent notes that Russian Energy Minister Novak requested a delay to the OPEC/OPEC+ meeting (originally scheduled for June 25/26) as a later date would give key participants the chance to discuss the issue more at the G-20 summit on June 28. The correspondent also notes of that Iranian officials are yet to agree on the new proposed dates to move the OPEC meeting from June to early July, according to sources and the current secretariat is looking at the option of holding OPEC meet in June and the non-OPEC in July. Elsewhere, gold (-0.4%) continues to fall at the whim of a firmer risk appetite, whilst in terms of base metals, copper (+0.9%) extends on its gains aided by the risk tone and Dalian iron ore surged 6% on supply woes amid expectations that  miners will be unable to expand output to meet higher steel demand. Subsequently, JPM modestly upgraded its Chinese steel demand and iron ore price forecasts, noting that the peak disruption “is likely behind us”.

Iranian officials are yet to agree on the new proposed dates to move the OPEC meeting from June to early July, according to sources via Energy Intelligence; adds secretariat is looking at the option of holding OPEC meet in June and the non-OPEC in July. (Twitter)

Pantheon Macroeconomics writes on the UK Labour Market Report:
content:
The on-balance strong labour market report strengthens the positions of both Haldane and Saunders in their expression of gradual rate increases.

Whilst the 3M employment figure looks weak this looks largely due to sampling volatility.

The Average weekly wages ex-bonus data hitting a May 2008 high was driven by a 1.9% increase in public sector wages, with private sector also rising by an above-trend 0.4%. The tight labour market has also played a role, with the maintenance of last years shift up in the median pay settlement to 2.5%.

As such, PM say that the MPC can’t afford to ignore the constant inflation pressure now emitted by the labour market.

Nomura Quants estimate that the risk-on mood could dissipate in 10 days if driven by the unwinding of bearish positions
content:
• The upturn in risk tone from neutral levels is unmatched as per their pattern trends, but when compared to past behaviour for gains on 5 consecutive trading days level the risk-on mood has tended to die down after only around ten trading days, specifically if it is being driven by unwinding of bearish positions.
  • If investors take on bullish positions, however, they believe that the risk-on mood may last up until the end of July, with the likelihood of a volatility shock in August derived from how much risk is taken on by speculators in July. The take up of bullish positions looks more likely should G20 go off without a hitch, and volatility remain muted in July.
  • CTAs seem to be switching to long positions in S&P 500 futures after having closed out shorts as the index approaches 2900, with mechanistic downside pressure muted as the majority of investors refute the possibility of a US recession. Global macro hedge funds have also been closing out US stock shorts.
  • Long-Short funds are largely unchanged in terms of exposure, but they have narrowed momentum shorts and high beta shorts, suggesting a risk-on mood forming below the surface.

content: Gilts got off to a modestly firmer start in line with expectations and an ongoing bounce in Bunds that reached 171.31 before petering out, but the 10 year UK debt future has now retreated from early Liffe highs of 130.42 to 130.11 vs Monday’s 130.34 settlement awaiting a scheduled speech from BoE’s Vlieghe to see if he chimes with the more hawkish line adopted by Haldane and Saunders of late. On that note the latter is due to talk again later alongside Broadbent at a joint TSC reappointment hearing, while Tenreyro is slated at the same time (10.00BST) elsewhere. Prior to all that the latest UK jobs and earnings data will be in focus, especially hot on the heels of yesterday’s downbeat GDP and production updates. Back to Liffe, initially slender losses across the Short Sterling strip are extending to as much as 4 ticks in some contracts.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board after a similar lead from US where sentiment was underpinned by the US-Mexico tariff relief which lifted the S&P 500 and DJIA to a 5-day and 6-day win streak respectively, although gains in the region were initially capped amid a lack of fresh catalysts. ASX 200 (+1.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) traded positive with early outperformance in Australia as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend and with Vocus Group the largest gainer following a takeover offer from AGL Energy, while the Japanese benchmark was just about kept afloat by a weaker currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) conformed to the upbeat tone despite another net liquidity drain by the PBoC and mixed comments by US President Trump who stated that a trade deal with China will work out because of tariffs but warned the next USD 300bln of tariffs will come into effect if Chinese President Xi does not come to the G20. Nonetheless, mainland China outperformed after China issued notice encouraging investment in local government special bonds issuance for project financing and amid reports that the PBoC may continue to support banks through various tools.

FTSE

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Ex-RBS executive Jim Brown will replace Peter Griffith as CEO of Co’s banking arm, according to Sky News citing sources. (Sky News)

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Co. signed an agreement to acquire Tatcha, terms undisclosed, sources state the deal value could be near USD 500mln. (Newswires)

HSBC (HSBA LN) – Co. stated that it is creating a USD 880mln tech fund to provide financing to early stage companies in southern China’s Greater Bay Area. (SCMP)

BP (BP/ LN) – Justice Ministry of Senegal has asked prosecutors to begin an enquiry into Senegal’s energy contracts, following reports that the Senegal President’s brother was involved in fraud relating to two offshore gas blocks developed by the Co. Previously, a report stated that the Co. paid around USD 10bln in royalties for the Timis Corporation’s stake. (Newswires)

Telecom Names – Telecom operators are to write to the UK Government asking them to clarify their position on Huawei, and seek a meeting between the government and industry names; according to a draft letter. (BBC)

Oil Names - WTI crude futures pared some of the prior day’s losses after prices rebounded from support near the USD 53.00/bbl with focus now shifting to the latest inventory numbers beginning with the API report after-hours later.

Mining Names - Gold traded sideways as USD consolidated and due to a lack of safe-haven demand, while copper prices benefitted from the risk appetite and as Chinese commodities gained including Dalian iron ore futures which surged by around 3% shortly after the open on tightening supply concerns.

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Siemens (SIE GY) – Co. have received a EUR 1.1bln order from Russian Railways for 13 high-speed trains, according to IFX. Elsewhere, Co. are said to be discussing JV opportunities in Russia with Grazprom. (Newswires)

Deutsche Post (DPW GY) – Co. is said to have dropped plans to IPO its electric van unit, according to sources. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW GY)/ Daimler (DAI GY)/ BMW (BMW GY) – Over the weekend, US and Mexico struck a deal to avert the implementation of US tariffs on Mexican goods. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are higher as sentiment remains supported on US-Mexico tariff relief
  • BoE’s Saunders says the BoE will likely need to return to a neutral stance sooner than expected and rates do not necessarily need to be on hold until Brexit uncertainty fades
  • Looking ahead highlights include, UK Employment Data, US NFIB & PPI, ECB’s Nowotny & Rehn, BoE’s Vlieghe, Saunders, Broadbent & Tenreyro. Supply from the US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were higher across the board after a similar lead from US where sentiment was underpinned by the US-Mexico tariff relief which lifted the S&P 500 and DJIA to a 5-day and 6-day win streak respectively, although gains in the region were initially capped amid a lack of fresh catalysts. ASX 200 (+1.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) traded positively with early outperformance in Australia as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend and with Vocus Group the largest gainer following a takeover offer from AGL Energy, while the Japanese benchmark was just about kept afloat by a weaker currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) conformed to the upbeat tone despite another net liquidity drain by the PBoC and mixed comments by US President Trump who stated that a trade deal with China will work out because of tariffs but warned the next USD 300bln of tariffs will come into effect if Chinese President Xi does not come to the G20. Nonetheless, mainland China outperformed after China issued notice encouraging investment in local government special bonds issuance for project financing and amid reports that the PBoC may continue to support banks through various tools. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as yields tracked the rebound in their US counterparts and with demand for Japanese bonds also sapped by gains in stocks and after weaker demand in the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds.

PBoC injected CNY 10bln via 7-day reverse repos for a daily net drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8930 (Prev. 6.8925)

PBoC may continue to support banks through various tools including RRR, MLF and SLF, while there were separate reports that Chinese companies have been scaling back or halting investment in the US market. (China Securities Journal/SCMP) 

UK/EU

BoE's Saunders (Hawk) said the BoE will likely need to return to neutral policy stance sooner than the market expects and that the MPC doesn't necessarily need to keep rates unchanged until Brexit uncertainties are resolved. Saunders added that BoE's neutral rate is around 2% and suggested that they should not just look at Brexit uncertainty and instead should look at growth as well as assess whether or not it is above or below potential when setting interest rate. (Newswires) For reference, the next BoE rate decision is on June 20th.

UK right-wing Tory caucus held a non-binding vote to gauge support in which Boris Johnson received the most votes as the results from the 92 Group vote showed Johnson received 34 votes, Raab at 18 votes, Gove at 6 votes, McVey at 6 votes, Harper at 5 votes, Javid at 5 votes, Hunt at 2 votes and Leadsom at 2 votes. (Newswires)

EU Source indicates that the idea of Boris Johnson in the European Council is ‘likely abhorrent’ to some EU leaders, with the source also critical of Dominic Raab. (Guardian)

UK Tory MP Iain Duncan Smith said he has decided to vote for Boris Johnson in the leadership election and backs him to deliver Brexit. (Telegraph)

Italy PM Conte will meet with Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio in approaching days to complete action plan for entire legislature and want to avert EU disciplinary action against Italy, while they will meet with Finance Minister Tria on budget package. (Newswires) 

FX

In FX markets, the greenback consolidated following the prior day’s choppy price action and as its major counterparts traded mixed in which EUR/USD was kept steady near support at 1.1300 and as GBP/USD lacked vigour after its recent slip below the 1.2700 handle. In terms of the latest news from the UK leadership race, the right-wing 92 Group within the Conservatives held a non-binding vote to gauge support in which former Foreign Minister and hardcore Brexiteer Boris Johnson received the most votes, while former party leader Iain Duncan Smith also backed Boris Johnson to deliver the Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY remained underpinned by risk sentiment and antipodeans were lacklustre in which NZD/USD gave up the 0.6600 handle and AUD/USD also failed to sustain the early upside which had been triggered by a surge in iron ore prices and strength in CNY in the wake of a firmer than expected PBoC fix. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly higher as the relief rally was sustained in which WTI crude futures pared some of the prior day’s losses after prices rebounded from support near the USD 53.00/bbl with focus now shifting to the latest inventory numbers beginning with the API report after-hours later. As a reminder, there were also recent comments from Russian Energy Minister Novak that suggested the scenario of oil prices falling to USD 30/bbl cannot be excluded should the output cut deal not be extended. Elsewhere, gold traded sideways as USD consolidated and due to a lack of safe-haven demand, while copper prices benefitted from the risk appetite and as Chinese commodities gained including Dalian iron ore futures which surged by around 3% shortly after the open on tightening supply concerns.

GEOPOLITCAL

North Korea state media called on the US to “withdraw its hostile policy” towards Pyongyang or agreements made at the Singapore summit 1 year ago may become “a blank sheet of paper". (Newswires)

Chinese press reports stated the US Air Force is preparing to run through aggressor drills to simulate combat with China's J-20 fighter jets, while it was also reported that China and Russia are expected to form an alliance to fend off the US. (SCMP)

The US government is reportedly considering further Iran sanctions which would focus on Iran's special trade and finance institute that works with Europe's Instex, while it was also reported that IAEA stated Iran has accelerated enrichment of uranium. (Newswires)

US

Yields were higher across the curve amid a more constructive risk tone after the US decided against implementing tariffs on Mexican imports. However, some attribute higher yields to positioning ahead of this week’s supply, with attention on whether foreign buyers are willing to scoop up Treasuries at the recently lower yields. Additionally, some will be mindful of the FOMC meeting next week, and for any nod to the recent dovish pricing of the FOMC rate trajectory (will the Fed shift from neutral to an easing bias?). There is also the CPI report on Wednesday, where a lower print might squash yields down towards the bottom of the recent ranges; conversely, CPI above expectations and a strong retail sales report (Friday) could provide a hurdle to the bullish thesis running in Treasuries. Monday also saw a large amount of corporate; IFR noted that high grade supply looked set to head towards USD 15bln or more on the day. At settlement, yields at the belly of the curve saw the most pronounced move, 10-year yield up just over 6bps, with the 2s/10s steepening c. 1.1bps. US T-note futures (M9) settled 14+ ticks lower at 126-14.

President Trump stated that the US has an agreement on something with Mexico that they will announce very soon and that he does not think Mexico will be denying for very long the undisclosed portion of the agreement. (Newswires/Twitter)

China Literature (772 HK) - Co. proposes 10% buyback. (Newswires)

GCL-Poly Holdings (3800 HK) - Co. is to place 1.51bln new shares at HKD 0.45/Shr vs. last close HKD 0.50 to raise HKD 680mln. (Newswires)

Geely Auto (175 HK) - Co. May sales fell 27% Y/Y to 90.3K units. (Newswires)

Financials - China is reportedly planning to tighten rules for smaller lending firms in which it seeks to raise the minimum registered capital requirement on small lending companies. (Newswires)

Local government bonds - China issued notice on local government special bonds issuance and project financing in which it encourages investment in local government bonds. (Newswires)

Trade - US President Trump said the trade deal with China will work out because of tariffs and that China will make a deal because they have to, while he believes that China are absolutely devaluing the CNY to offset tariffs. Furthermore, Trump commented that tariffs will rise if a deal with China is not made and that he thinks he will meet with Chinese President Xi at the G20 summit in Osaka but added that its fine if they don't and that the next USD 300bln of tariffs will come into effect if Chinese President Xi does not come to the G20. (Newswires)

Other News - PBoC may continue to support banks through various tools including RRR, MLF and SLF. (China Securities Journal)

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE NEWS: May sales updates from Acer, AU Optronics, Chunghwa Telecom, Fosconn, MediaTek and TSMC
content:
TAIWAN

Acer (2353 TT) - Co. May sales fell 11.0% Y/Y to TWD 16.7bln. (Newswires)

AU Optronics (2409 TT) - Co. May sales fell 3.9% Y/Y to TWD 24.7bln. (Newswires)

China Airlines (2610 TT) - Co. May revenue rose 4.0% Y/Y to TWD 13.7bln. (Newswires)

China Steel Corp (2002 TT - Co. May sales fell 7.5% Y/Y to TWD 32.4bln. (Newswires) Chunghwa Telecom (2412) - Co. May sales fell 14.4% Y/Y to TWD 16.7bln. (Newswires)

EVA airways (2618 TT) - Co. May sales rose 4.0% Y/Y to TWD 14.8bln. (Newswires)

Far Eastern New Century (1402 TT) - Co. May sales rose 24.5% Y/Y to TWD 23.0bln. (Newswires)

Foxconn Technology (2354 TT) - Co. May sales fell 22.6% Y/Y to TWD 8.12bln. (Newswires)

Inventec (2356 TT) - Co. May rev. TWD 40.9bln vs. Prev. TWD 43.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

MediaTek (2454 TT) - Co. May sales fell 6.3% Y/Y to TWD 19.1bln. (Newswires)

Quanta (2382 TT) - Co. May sales rose 21.1% Y/Y to TWD 88.7bln. (Newswires)

TSMC (2330 TT) - Co. May sales rose 0.7% Y/Y to TWD 80.4bln. (Newswires) 

Data Recap

  • Taiwan Trade Balance (USD)(May) 4.5B vs. Exp. 3.5B (Prev. 2.7B). (Newswires)
  • Taiwan Exports (May) Y/Y -4.8% vs. Exp. -3.5% (Prev. -3.3%)
  • Taiwan Imports (May) Y/Y -5.9% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. 2.6%)

 

SINGAPORE

CapitaLand (CAPL) - Co. announced proposed divestment of stakes in 3 companies holding retail malls in China for CNY 2.96bln to CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT SP). (Newswires)
